filmsoscar.director: Directed by Charlie Chaplin United States, 1940
filmsoscar.name: THE GREAT DICTATOR
filmsoscar.synopsis: After dedicated service in WWI, a Jewish barber spends years in an army hospital, unaware of the rise of a fascist, anti-Semitic dictator, whom he bears an uncanny resemblance to. When he returns to his neighborhood, he is stunned by the brutal changes, and recklessly joins a girl in rebelling.
filmsoscar.our_take: Charlie vs. Adolf! In his most controversial film yet (as well as his first “talkie”), Chaplin took on fascism with subversive humor, trademark slapstick, and a feast of now-classic scenes. The final speech is legendary, and the “globe dance” is wicked and perverse. An absolute essential.

actors.name: CHARLIE CHAPLIN
actors.cast: EDITING, SCREENPLAY, PRODUCER, MUSIC, CAST, DIRECTOR

filmsoscar.name: THE HUNT
filmsoscar.synopsis: A middle-aged kindergarten teacher is slowly piecing his life back together following a divorce and custody battle. He has a new love, a new job and is patching things up with his estranged son. But a little white lie from one of his student is about to shatter his newfound luck.
filmsoscar.our_take: International star Mads Mikkelsen picked up the Best Actor prize at Cannes for what’s become one of the most acclaimed arthouse films of that decade: Thomas Vinterberg’s provocative allegory of mass hysteria, tightly plotted, with an ending to leave you rattled.

filmsoscar.name: TALK TO HER
filmsoscar.synopsis: Benigno is infatuated with Alicia, a dancer he watches from the anonymity of his apartment. After an accident, she is brought to the hospital where Benigno happens to be her caregiver. When wounded bullfighter Lydia is brought into the same ward, her companion, Marco, bonds with Benigno.
filmsoscar.our_take: Winner of a Best Original Screenplay Oscar, Talk To Her boasts a sublimely improbable premise making for a perfect distillation of modern melodrama. This darkly exquisite version of Sleeping Beauty, where wounds and desire become indiscernible, is a transcendent celebration of male vulnerability.

filmsoscar.director: Directed by Paweł Pawlikowski Poland, France, 2018
filmsoscar.name: COLD WAR
filmsoscar.synopsis: A man and a woman meet in the ruins of post-war Poland. Wiktor’s attention is immediately captured by Zula, an ambitious and captivating young woman. With vastly different backgrounds and temperaments, they are fatally mismatched and yet drawn to each other.
filmsoscar.our_take: Peering behind the iron curtain of 1950s Poland, Paweł Pawlikowski’s melancholic, jazzy period piece ruminates on the possibility of borderless love in an ideologically polarized world. An exquisitely shot, black-and-white gem nominated for 3 Academy Awards including Best Director.

filmsoscar.name: THE 400 BLOWS
filmsoscar.synopsis: The 400 Blows traces 14-year-old Antoine Doinel’s odyssey through a life of aloof parents, oppressive teachers and petty crime. A loner on the brink of rebellion, Antoine is buoyed along the way by a touching friendship, a love of cinema, and the hope of escape.
filmsoscar.our_take: By blowing up the established credos of French cinema, François Truffaut’s defiant, semi-autobiographical debut feature put the Nouvelle Vague on the world stage. An iconic 14-year-old (!) Jean-Pierre Léaud plays a rebellious youth in his first of many turns as Truffaut’s cinematic alter ego.

filmsoscar.director: Directed by Pedro Almodóvar Spain, France, 1999
filmsoscar.name: ALL ABOUT MY MOTHER
filmsoscar.synopsis: Following the tragic death of her teenage son, Manuela travels from Madrid to Barcelona in an attempt to contact the long-estranged father the boy never knew. She reunites with an old friend, an outspoken transgender sex worker, and befriends a troubled actress and a pregnant, HIV-positive nun.
filmsoscar.our_take: One of Almodóvar’s most acclaimed and beloved films, All About My Mother won the Best Director award in Cannes and an Oscar! An immaculate maximalist melodrama full of intense emotion, this love letter to actresses is brought to life by a fierce cast of Almodóvar regulars, including Penélope Cruz.

filmsoscar.name: THREE COLORS: RED
filmsoscar.synopsis: Part-time model Valentine meets a retired judge who lives in her neighborhood after she runs over his dog. At first the judge gifts her with the dog, but her boyfriend won’t allow her to keep it. When she returns to the judge’s house, she finds him listening in on his neighbors’ conversations.
filmsoscar.our_take: Sumptuously stylish and sexy, this modern classic takes an unconventional look at fate, love, and chance in an interconnected society. Starring Irène Jacob, it was an Academy Award nominee for Best Director and Screenplay and i

filmsoscar.name: NIGHTS OF CABIRIA
filmsoscar.synopsis: Rome, 1957. A woman, Cabiria, is robbed and left to drown by her boyfriend, Giorgio. Rescued, she resumes her life and tries her best to find happiness in a cynical world. Even when she thinks her struggles are over and she has found happiness and contentment, things may not be what they seem.
filmsoscar.our_take: Giulietta Masina took home the best actress prize from Cannes for her spectacular turn in this Fellini classic. Before his baroque surrealist epics, Fellini made the most intimate of character driven films, of which Nights of Cabiria stands at the forefront with unmatched warmth, charm, and heart.

filmsoscar.name: VOLVER
filmsoscar.synopsis: In working-class Madrid, Raimunda needs to deal with her husband’s death, while struggling to support her family. But surrounded by three generations of women—her sister Sole, her daughter Paula, and friend Agustina—and haunted by her dead mother, Raimunda will do more than survive.
filmsoscar.our_take: Fronted by a divine Penélope Cruz alongside an ensemble cast of Almodóvar regulars like Carmen Maura and Lola Dueñas, Volver is a vibrant generational melodrama about Spanish womanhood and resilience. Almodóvar explores how the ghosts of our past come to haunt us and what we can do to atone.

filmsoscar.director: Directed by Andrea Arnold United Kingdom, 2003
filmsoscar.name: WASP
filmsoscar.synopsis: A poor single mother of four must figure out what to do with her children after the guy she fancies asks her on a date, determined not to let them become an obstacle in her pursuit of a relationship.
filmsoscar.our_take: Reminiscent of the social realism found in her latest triumph Cow, Andrea Arnold’s bracing, Oscar-winning short was shot on location in her hometown of Dartford. Packing a hefty emotional punch, the film confronts the brutality of working-class motherhood with astonishing frankness and empathy.

filmsoscar.director: Directed by Jacques Tati France, Italy, 1958
filmsoscar.name: MON ONCLE
filmsoscar.synopsis: Set loose in a society of gaudy materialism, the amiably oblivious Monsieur Hulot finds himself hilariously out of sorts when visiting his sister, brother-in-law, and nephew at their bourgeois house—the geometric Villa Arpel, filled with oppressively bewildering and ultramodern “conveniences.”
filmsoscar.our_take: For his first film in color, and his second as the legendary Monsieur Hulot, Jacques Tati won an Academy Award for the spectacular visual comedy Mon Oncle—an enormously entertaining film that nonetheless manages to pack quite the punch, poking fun at the new social and economic order of modern life.

filmsoscar.director: Directed by Spike Lee United States, 1992
filmsoscar.name: MALCOLM_X
filmsoscar.synopsis: A tribute to the controversial black activist and leader of the struggle for black liberation. He hit bottom during his imprisonment in the ’50s, he became a Black Muslim and then a leader in the Nation of Islam. His assassination in 1965 left a legacy of self-determination and racial pride.
filmsoscar.our_take: A bravura biopic from writer-director Spike Lee (Do the Right Thing, BlacKkKansman), this insightful, engrossing epic does full justice to its subject: civil rights leader Malcolm X. A nuanced exploration of the man and the myth, anchored by a rousing performance from Denzel Washington.

filmSpotlight.director: Directed by Christian Petzold Germany, France, 2018
filmSpotlight.name: TRANSIT
filmSpotlight.synopsis: As a modern-day Paris is invaded by foreign troops, German refugee Georg flees to Marseille assuming the identity of a deceased writer. There he delves into the delicate culture of the refugee community, becomes involved in the lives of a mother and son, and meets the writer’s enigmatic wife Marie.
filmSpotlight.our_take: A WW2 novel about the German invasion of France, mistaken identity, unrequited love, and a need to escape—but staged in familiar, modern settings. We’re thrown into a relatable world, with characters that we deeply want to win, facing a situation that we realise could return in the 21st Century. -VM

filmSpotlight.name: THE GUILTY
filmSpotlight.synopsis: A police officer is demoted to deskwork and answers a phone call from a kidnapped woman. Confined to the police station, the search to find the missing woman will take all his intuition and skill, as his own personal demons conspire against him.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Inspired by the podcast Serial, this debut feature from Gustav Möller is a nerve-wracking police thriller set within the confines of one room. Equal parts psychological portrait and shocking mystery, The Guilty’s ingenious screenplay gives rise to an enthralling performance by Jakob Cedergren.

filmSpotlight.director: Directed by Lars von Trier Denmark, Sweden, 2018
filmSpotlight.name: THE HOUSE THAT JACK BUILT
filmSpotlight.synopsis: Failed architect Jack recounts his elaborately orchestrated murders. Told from his point of view, he sees each one as a towering work of art that defines his life’s work as a serial killer. As the police is drawing nearer, Jack takes greater risks in his attempt to create the ultimate artwork.
filmSpotlight.our_take: A virtuosic act of defiance against his detractors, Lars Von Trier’s The House that Jack Built is a brilliant, ultra-violent portrayal of a serial killer. Starring a mesmeric Matt Dillon on terrifying form, this Dantean plunge into the mind of madness is a provocative blend of comedy and horror.

filmSpotlight.name: VITALINA VARELA
filmSpotlight.synopsis: When her husband leaves to find work in Portugal, Vitalina is left behind in Cape Verde. Years later, she finally makes the journey to Lisbon, but arrives three days after his funeral. Alone and isolated in her late husband’s home, she is determined to persevere and confront the ghosts of the past.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Luminary Pedro Costa’s unique, collaborative style of portraiture reaches a magnificent peak in Vitalina Varela. Amongst haunting chiaroscuro compositions, Varela’s real-life stories of love, migration, and deceit take the form of bewitching incantations—and earned her Locarno’s Best Actress award!

filmSpotlight.director: Directed by Mounia Meddour Gens France, 2019
filmSpotlight.name: PAPICHA
filmSpotlight.synopsis: Nedjma, an 18 year-old student passionate about fashion design refuses to let the tragic events of the Algerian Civil War to keep her from experiencing a normal life. As the social climate becomes more conservative, she rejects the new bans set by the radicals and decides to put on a fashion show.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Winner of the César award for Best First Film, this captivating tale of political resistance from Mounia Meddour is bursting with energy. Exquisitely crafted, and with a remarkable lead in César-winning actress Lyna Khoudri, Papicha is a hymn to female empowerment in the face of cultural oppression.

filmSpotlight.name: THE PAINTER AND THE THIEF
filmSpotlight.synopsis: Desperate for answers about the theft of her 2 paintings, a Czech artist seeks out and befriends the career criminal who stole them. After inviting her thief to sit for a portrait, the two form an improbable relationship and an inextricable bond that will forever link these lonely souls.
filmSpotlight.our_take: It’s impossible not to wheel out the aphorism that truth is stranger than fiction when faced with this astonishing documentary. A slippery, reflexive study in compassion and portraiture, The Painter and the Thief confronts the ethical boundaries of art as a tool for intervention and recovery.

filmSpotlight.director: Directed by Paweł Pawlikowski Poland, France, 2018
filmSpotlight.name: COLD WAR
filmSpotlight.synopsis: A man and a woman meet in the ruins of post-war Poland. Wiktor’s attention is immediately captured by Zula, an ambitious and captivating young woman. With vastly different backgrounds and temperaments, they are fatally mismatched and yet drawn to each other.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Peering behind the iron curtain of 1950s Poland, Paweł Pawlikowski’s melancholic, jazzy period piece ruminates on the possibility of borderless love in an ideologically polarized world. An exquisitely shot, black-and-white gem nominated for 3 Academy Awards including Best Director.

filmSpotlight.name: THE HUMAN VOICE
filmSpotlight.synopsis: A woman watches time passing next to the suitcases of her ex-lover (who is supposed to come pick them up, but never arrives) and a restless dog who doesn’t understand that his master has abandoned him. Two living beings facing abandonment.
filmSpotlight.our_take: For his English-language debut, our favourite Spanish auteur Pedro Almodóvar teams up with Tilda Swinton for a loose adaptation of Jean Cocteau’s timeless play. Swinton delivers a spellbinding solo performance, in which vulnerability and despair turn into a monologue of magnificent obsession.

filmSpotlight.director: Directed by Ken Loach United Kingdom, France, 2019
filmSpotlight.name: SORRY WE MISSED YOU
filmSpotlight.synopsis: Ricky and his family have been fighting an uphill battle against debt since the 2008 financial crash. An opportunity to regain some independence appears by becoming a self-employed delivery driver, but when he and his wife are pulled in different directions, everything will come to a breaking point.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Britain’s pre-eminent auteur of politically-engaged social realism, Ken Loach followed up his Palme d’Or win for I, Daniel Blake with this scathing indictment of the gig economy. Powerfully intimate, Sorry We Missed You is a fierce condemnation of the ruinous practices of the modern job market.

filmSpotlight.director: Directed by Cristi Puiu Romania, Serbia, 2020
filmSpotlight.name: MALMKROG
filmSpotlight.synopsis: Among the guests who come to the mansion of aristocratic landowner Nikolai over Christmas are a politician, a young countess, and a general with his wife. They dine and discuss topics such as progress and morality. As the debate becomes more heated, cultural differences become increasingly apparent.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Grand themes and heated discussions are served at a 19th century Christmas Eve dinner party in this major, Berlinale-winning work from Cristi Puiu. Formally elegant yet wryly punctuated, Malmkrog tightens its dialectical screws with one eye on the present, the other on droll, Buñuelian ironies.

filmSpotlight.name: DAYS
filmSpotlight.synopsis: Kang wanders through a lonely urban landscape and seeks treatment in Hong Kong for a chronic illness; at the same time, a young Laotian immigrant named Non works in Bangkok. These two solitary men eventually come together in a moment of healing, tenderness, and sexual release.
filmSpotlight.our_take: Tsai Ming-liang and Lee Kang-sheng’s masterwork is one of their simplest and sweetest propositions. A dialogue-free ode to carnal and spiritual longing that speaks profoundly to our contemporary moment, Days is a film about kinship, healing, and curative connections that tingles with anticipation.

filmSpotlight.name: SUMMER OF 85
filmSpotlight.synopsis: When 16-year-old Alexis is caught up in the deceitful Normandy sea, David heroically saves him from drowning. And, this is how Alexis meets the person of his life. But, how long will this tumultuous, dreamy relationship last? Will the dream last for more than one summer, the summer of 85
filmSpotlight.our_take: A ravishing 1980s time capsule, François Ozon’s queer romance whisks us off to the French coast where the sun shines bright and earworms from The Cure and Bananarama are on at full blast. Like the changing ocean tides, the wistful fleetingness of youth only intensifies the passions of first love.

MubiPod.director: Directed by Pelin Esmer Turkey, Germany, 2012
MubiPod.name: WATCHTOWER
MubiPod.synopsis: Haunted by a tragic incident, Nihat isolates himself by becoming a fire warden in an observation tower in the wilderness. Seher lives in a makeshift room at a rural bus station, and works as a bus hostess to escape her own traumatic past. Destined to come to a crossroads, their fates soon collide.
MubiPod.our_take: Pelin Esmer’s third film (yet her first work of pure fiction) movingly looks at the hidden tragedies that ordinary people face in their lives. In this meditative melodrama about an incongruous couple overcoming their trauma, Esmer patiently explores the emotions of individuals isolated from society.

MubiPod.director: Directed by Sebastián Leli Chile, Spain, 2013
MubiPod.name: GLORIA
MubiPod.synopsis: Gloria is a 58 year old divorcée. Her children have all left home but she has no desire to spend her days and nights alone. Determined to defy old age and loneliness, she rushes headlong into a whirl of singles’ parties on the hunt for instant gratification…
MubiPod.our_take: Sebastián Lelio’s breakout success is a spinning, invigorating, and heart-warming film which told the world that middle-aged women could be the most complex and touching characters in cinema. This year Lelio re-made his own movie with Julianne Moore, but we adore the enchanting Paulina García

MubiPod.name: HORSE MONEY
MubiPod.synopsis: Pedro Costa’s film follows Ventura, as he traverses a seemingly endless night steeped in sinister chiaroscuro and populated by the ghosts of his past. From the restless spirits that haunt this decaying urban landscape, Costa turns his exploration of memory into a spellbinding cinematic experience.
MubiPod.our_take: From Portugal’s greatest living filmmaker comes this dreamlike hallucination of a lost soul belonging to the country’s repressed, abused, misused and forgotten underclass. With his rivetingly poetic political cinema, Pedro Costa gives the unheard and unseen a voice and a true cinematic presence.

MubiPod.director: Directed by María Alché Argentina, Brazil, 2018
MubiPod.name: A FAMILY SUBMERGED
MubiPod.synopsis: Marcela’s world becomes strange after her sister dies. While she grieves, Marcela also purges her sister’s flat. When a friend of her daughter’s offers to help, she finds unexpected comfort, and their relationship deepens. During these confusing days, Marcela’s past and present become intertwined.

MubiPod.director: Directed by CHARLIE CHAPLIN UNITED STATES 1936
MubiPod.name: MODERN TIMES
MubiPod.synopsis: Subjected to the infernal production rate of the factory, the Little Tramp suddenly has a nervous breakdown. From hospital, to prison, to unemployment, he gets caught up in the sprockets and cogs of modern industrialization. That is, until he comes across a kind orphaned girl.
MubiPod.our_take: Possibly Chaplin’s greatest masterpiece—though with so many, who’s to say?—Modern Times contains some of the comic’s most brilliantly iconic and politically savvy routines. A biting satire of modern industrialized society, Chaplin staved off the 20th-century (and sound cinema) with wit and elegance.

actors.name: CHARLIE CHAPLIN
actors.cast: EDITING, SCREENPLAY, PRODUCER, MUSIC, CAST, DIRECTOR

MubiPod.name: THE GLEANERS AND I
MubiPod.synopsis: Varda’s rumination on this art of “living off the leftovers of others” finds inspiration in both past and present, rural and urban, the political and the highly personal. Camera in hand, Varda interviews those for whom gleaning is a way of life, or an encompassing philosophy.
MubiPod.our_take: Always one to break new ground, Agnès Varda puts together what is simply one of the greatest documentaries of all time. Warm, generous, and very human, this late-career triumph showcases her self-reflexive filming and constant hunt for raw material, finding beauty in the most unexpected of places.

MubiPod.name: THE HUNT
MubiPod.synopsis: A middle-aged kindergarten teacher is slowly piecing his life back together following a divorce and custody battle. He has a new love, a new job and is patching things up with his estranged son. But a little white lie from one of his student is about to shatter his newfound luck.
MubiPod.our_take: International star Mads Mikkelsen picked up the Best Actor prize at Cannes for what’s become one of the most acclaimed arthouse films of that decade: Thomas Vinterberg’s provocative allegory of mass hysteria, tightly plotted, with an ending to leave you rattled.

MubiPod.director: Directed by Charlie Chaplin United States, 1931
MubiPod.name: CITY LIGHTS
MubiPod.synopsis: A lovable tramp falls for a blind woman who sells flowers on the street and who mistakes him for a millionaire. Upon learning that she and her grandmother are to be evicted, the tramp undertakes a series of attempts to provide them with the money they need, all of which end in humiliating failure.
MubiPod.our_take: With Chaplin at his peak, comedy is to be expected. But this renowned classic is also a terrific display of how touching he could be, combining humor with tenderness, slapstick with longing. Although this Depression-era comedy was made after the advent of sound, Chaplin stayed resolutely silent.

actors.name: CHARLIE CHAPLIN
actors.cast: EDITING, SCREENPLAY, PRODUCER, MUSIC, CAST, DIRECTOR

MubiPod.director: Directed by José Luis Valle Mexico, 2013
MubiPod.name: LAS BÚSQUEDAS
MubiPod.synopsis: Ulises wants to kill the man who stole his wallet, in which he kept the unique photo of his dead daughter. Elvira wants to understand her husband, who had his dog put down and returned home to commit suicide. Both try to fill the void left by their loved ones. The pain of their loss unites them.
MubiPod.our_take: The lives of three strangers become entangled in this stunning fable from José Luis Valle. Shot in crisp black-and-white on the streets of Mexico City in 7 days, The Searches is a minimalist examination of social and gender hierarchies that—with an eye for romance and revenge—tips its hat to noir.

MubiPod.director: Directed by Pablo Larraín Chile, Mexico, 2010
MubiPod.name: POST MORTEM
MubiPod.synopsis: In the midst of Pinochet’s 1973 military coup in Chile, bodies pile up in the morgue. Anyone protesting at the way corpses are treated is regarded as an enemy. Mortuary worker Mario says nothing. Instead he tries to get closer to his neighbor, cabaret dancer Nancy, but she suddenly disappears.
MubiPod.our_take: A chilly, slow-burning drama, Post Mortem is simultaneously droll and stark, witnessing a political nightmare in super-widescreen and with a distinctly offbeat sensibility. Pablo Larraín’s second instalment in his unintentional dictatorship-era trilogy

MubiPod.director: Directed by Pablo Larraín Chile, Brazil, 2008
MubiPod.name: TONY MANERO
MubiPod.synopsis: Santiago de Chile, 1978. In the midst of Pinochet’s dictatorship, Raúl Peralta, a man in his 50s, is obsessed with impersonating John Travolta’s character in Saturday Night Fever. And his dream of being recognized is about to become a reality when the national television announces a contest.
MubiPod.our_take: Pablo Larraín has been making politically cutting and darkly comic sharp autopsies of the past in his native Chile since this Quinzaine breakthrough. Tony Manero, a satirical psychological study and the first part of a thematic trilogy about life under Pinochet, is biting, confrontative cinema.

MubiPod.diretor: Directed by Israel Cárdenas, Laura Amelia Guzmán Mexico, United Kingdom, 2007
MubiPod.name: COCHOCH
MubiPod.synopsis: Story of Evaristo and Luis Antonio – indigenous brothers from the Sierra Tarahumara in northwest Mexico – who have just graduated from boarding elementary school.
MubiPod.our_take: A fable on cultural identity where the adventures of two Rarámuri brothers brings to life the search for oneself amid adversity. This critical portrait of the Indigenous Rarámuri culture and everyday life in Mexico’s Sierra Tarahumara offers a vivid portrayal of the passage into adulthood.

FilmOfTheDay.name: LET THE SUNSHINE IN
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Isabelle is a successful painter living in Paris, whose apparent independence belies what she desires most: real romantic fulfillment. Isabelle reveals deep wells of yearning, vulnerability, and resilience as she tumbles into relationships with all the wrong men.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: A Claire Denis romcom? We’re sold! Subverting fairytale tropes with fine irony, this wonderfully unpredictable take on middle-age female desire and the volatility of emotions stars an exquisitely mercurial Juliette Binoche—searching for love, encountering mostly disappointment. Oh, and that ending!

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Ryusuke Hamaguch Japan, France, 2018
FilmOfTheDay.name: ASAKO I & II
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Asako is a young woman who meets and falls madly in love with a drifter, Baku, who one day drifts right out of her life. Two years later, in Tokyo, Asako sees Baku again—or, rather, a young, solid businessman named Ryohei who bears a striking resemblance to her old flame.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: What better way to celebrate Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s Oscar win for Drive My Car than to immerse yourself in his earlier Vertigo-inspired romance mystery! Lovingly devoted to the innermost feelings and fluctuations of its characters, Asako I & II hums to a lively soundtrack by J-Pop star Tofubeats.

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Pier Paolo Pasolini Italy, France, 1969
FilmOfTheDay.name: PIGSTY
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: The story of a cannibal in a medieval wasteland is interwoven with that of the son of an ex-Nazi industrialist in modern day Germany. The young German, who is more attracted to pigs than to his fiancée, and the cannibal become sacrificial victims of their different societies.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: A dazzling fusion of past and present, a two-pronged surrealist story of cannibalism and courtship, and a blow to the bourgeoisie that still stings. Starring arthouse royalty Jean-Pierre Léaud & Pierre Clémenti, Pigsty is a cult marvel on moral decay from one of cinema’s great visionaries, Pasolini.

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Julio Medem Spain, France, 1998
FilmOfTheDay.name: LOVERS OF THE ARCTIC CIRCLE
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Otto and Ana are lovers who meet at the age of eight and remain inextricably linked from that moment on. As their relationship develops through the years, they find themselves drawn to the mysteries of Finland’s hinterland—which stretches right into the Arctic Circle.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: With its innovative, elliptical narrative structure and its metaphysical depiction of a sinuous love affair, Lovers of the Arctic Circle rightly became an emblematic work of Spanish cinema. Julio Medem (Sex and Lucía) captured the hearts of a generation with his quasi-mystical look at fated love.

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Erick Zonca France, United States, 2008
FilmOfTheDay.name: JULIA
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: 40-year-old Julia is an alcoholic struggling to maintain her lifestyle of partying and one-night stands. She is a compulsive liar surviving on nickel-and-dime jobs. But when her desire and desperation drive her to commit an extremely violent act, she is forced to choose between life and death.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: After the startling success of his debut The Dreamlife of Angels and an immediate follow-up, we had to wait 8 years until Erick Zonca made this searing, deeply personal thriller. A fearless Tilda Swinton delivers one of the great performances as a self-destructive woman who’s gone off the rails.

FilmOfTheDay.name: DRIVE MY CAR
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Two years after his wife’s death, Yusuke Kafuku receives an offer to direct a play at a theater festival in Hiroshima. There, he meets Misaki, a reserved young woman assigned to be his chauffeur. As they spend time together, Kafuku starts to confront the mystery of his wife that quietly haunts him.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: Winning the Oscar, BAFTA, and Golden Globe for International Feature, Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s expansive Haruki Murakami adaptation is a film of engrossing pleasures. In detailing the effects of the past and the present, of memory and imagination on the creation of art, Drive My Car contains multitudes.

FilmOfTheDay.name: IRREVERSIBLE
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: A woman’s lover and her ex-boyfriend take justice into their own hands after she becomes the victim of a rapist. Because some acts can’t be undone. Because man is an animal. Because the desire for vengeance is a natural impulse. Because most crimes remain unpunished.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: Starring Vincent Cassel and Monica Bellucci, provocateur Gaspar Noé’s infamous backtracking revenge thriller is groundbreaking, offensive and frightening, causing much controversy at its premiere in Cannes. Brutal and possibly cruel, it is a dark story audaciously told—not for the faint-hearted!

actors.name: GASPAR NOÉ
actors.cast: DIRECTOR, SCREENPLAY, CINEMATOGRAPHY, EDITING, CAST, PRODUCER

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Lynne Ramsay United Kingdom, France, 2017
FilmOfTheDay.name: YOU WERE NEVER REALLY HERE
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: The tormented veteran Joe tracks down missing girls for a living. However, when he sets out to rescue the kidnapped daughter of a US Senator from a sex trafficking ring, things go horribly wrong. As he finds himself weathering a storm of corruption and vengeance, nightmares start to overtake him.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: After a six year absence, Lynne Ramsay returned with this stripped-to-the-bone adaptation of Jonathan Ames’ muscular novella. Featuring a powerhouse lead performance from Joaquin Phoenix, and a mesmerising Jonny Greenwood score, this enigmatic thriller is a triumph of form and psychological texture.

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Pier Paolo Pasolini Italy, 1967
FilmOfTheDay.name: OEDIPUS REX
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Oedipus Rex opens in 1920s Italy, recounting a birth that is the product of a bourgeoise’s affair with a military officer. The mid section depicts the myth of Oedipus, one of patricide and incest. An epilogue finds Oedipus playing his flute for a bustling citizenry in 1960s Bologna.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: Following The Gospel According to Matthew, Pier Paolo Pasolini turned to another classical text for this deeply personal take on Sophocles’ immortal tragedy. Hopping from Morocco to Bologna for his first film shot in color, Pasolini fashions a hugely ambitious, three-part epic of modern mythmaking.

FilmOfTheDay.name: MADE IN U.S.A
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Paula Nelson, a hard boiled detective, goes to Atlantic City to meet her lover. Once there, she learns that he is dead and decides to investigate. In her hotel room, she kills a man whose body is later found in the apartment of writer David Goodis. Paula will soon be arrested and interrogated.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: In this self-conscious and colourful film noir, Jean-Luc Godard delivers both the most extreme and exuberant expression of his bombastic pop-art filmmaking, and an indication of his turn to leftist politics. His last film with Anna Karina, featuring an unforgettable cameo from Marianne Faithfull.

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Paolo Sorrentino Italy, France, 2013
FilmOfTheDay.name: THE GREAT BEAUTY
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Jep Gambardella, a 65-year-old journalist, lives among Rome’s decadent high society in a swirl of rooftop parties and late-night soirees. But when he learns of the death of his friend’s wife, a woman he once loved, his life is thrown into perspective and he begins to see the world through new eyes.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: An ornate and eye-popping extravaganza, Paolo Sorrentino’s dazzling, suitably self-conscious spectacle conceals a despairing satire, a nauseous indictment of the glamorous facade and moral bankruptcy of Italy’s recent Berlusconi era. Winner of the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language film.

FilmOfTheDay.director: Directed by Sara Colangelo United States, 2018
FilmOfTheDay.name: THE KINDERGARTEN TEACHER
FilmOfTheDay.synopsis: Lisa Spinelli, married and living with kids that mostly ignore her, plods through her days teaching kindergarten with growing numbness. But one day everything changes—Lisa discovers that a five-year-old boy in her class may be the poet she can only dream of being. She becomes fascinated.
FilmOfTheDay.our_take: Sara Colangelo won a directing award in Sundance for her remake of Nadav Lapid’s film, starring Maggie Gyllenhaal—also a producer—at her very best! This riveting tale of obsession and disenchantment ambiguously questions what might be the role of art in our everyday life and personal development.
